What's the role of lactate threshold training in Hyrox and how does it differ from VO2max training?

Both lactate threshold (LT) and VO2max training are essential for Hyrox, but they serve completely different physiological purposes. Understanding the distinction will make your training more targeted and effective.

**Lactate Threshold — the sustainable pace ceiling:**

Your lactate threshold (LT2) is the intensity above which lactate accumulates faster than your body can clear it. Below LT2, you can sustain effort for extended periods. Above it, the clock is ticking — the higher you go, the faster you'll fatigue.

For Hyrox athletes, LT2 determines your sustainable running pace. The Brandt et al. (2025) data shows that running occupies 50-60% of race time at an intensity that's overwhelmingly aerobic but persistently above resting lactate (average blood lactate during runs was 7.7 mmol/L — well above the typical 4 mmol/L threshold).

This tells us something critical: **Hyrox running is done ABOVE lactate threshold** because the stations keep spiking your lactate and you never fully clear it during runs. The higher your LT2, the more margin you have. If your threshold is at 4:20/km and you're running at 4:30/km in a Hyrox race, you have a 10-second buffer. If your threshold is at 4:40/km, you're racing right at the edge — any station-induced lactate spike pushes you over and you slow dramatically.

**How to train LT2:**

| Protocol | Prescription | Frequency |
|---|---|---|
| Tempo runs | 20-40 min continuous at 85-88% HRmax ("comfortably hard") | 1x/week |
| Cruise intervals | 3 x 10-15 min at LT2 pace with 2-3 min jog recovery | 1x every 2 weeks |
| Progressive runs | 30-45 min building from Zone 2 to threshold in the final 10-15 min | 1x/week (alternating with tempo) |

**VO2max — the aerobic ceiling:**

VO2max is the maximum amount of oxygen your body can use during exercise. It's your aerobic ceiling — the absolute upper limit. VO2max is the #1 predictor of Hyrox finish time (r = -0.71).

While LT2 determines your sustainable running pace, VO2max determines how HIGH that pace can eventually reach. Think of it this way: VO2max is the size of your engine. LT2 is the percentage of that engine you can sustain without overheating.

A higher VO2max means:
- Your LT2 occurs at a faster absolute pace
- Race-intensity effort represents a lower percentage of your max capacity
- You have more headroom when stations spike your intensity
- You recover faster between stations because your aerobic system clears metabolic byproducts faster

**How to train VO2max:**

| Protocol | Prescription | Frequency |
|---|---|---|
| Norwegian 4x4 | 4 min at 85-95% HRmax, 3 min jog recovery, 4 rounds | 1x/week |
| Hinshaw-style intervals | 3 sets x 4 x 400m with 40 sec rest between reps, 4 min between sets | 1x every 2 weeks |
| Sugarcane protocol | 3-5 rounds at max sustainable pace, matched rest | 1x every 2 weeks |

**The key difference in training effect:**

| | Lactate Threshold | VO2max |
|---|---|---|
| **What it improves** | Sustainable pace, lactate clearance rate, metabolic efficiency | Maximal oxygen uptake, aerobic ceiling, recovery between efforts |
| **Intensity** | Zone 3 (70-80% HRmax) — "comfortably hard" | Zone 4-5 (85-95% HRmax) — "hard to very hard" |
| **Duration of intervals** | 10-40 min continuous or near-continuous | 3-5 min work intervals |
| **RPE** | 6-7/10 | 8-9/10 |
| **Hyrox application** | Running pace between stations | Recovery capacity after stations, absolute race-pace ceiling |
| **Training frequency** | 1-2x/week | 1x/week |
| **Adaptation timeline** | Noticeable in 4-6 weeks | Noticeable in 6-8 weeks |

**How they work together for Hyrox:**

Imagine VO2max as a 10-story building. LT2 is the floor you can live on comfortably. If your building is 10 stories (VO2max) and you live on floor 7 (LT2), you have 3 floors of headroom. If your building is 8 stories and you live on floor 7, you only have 1 floor of headroom — any spike pushes you to the roof.

VO2max training raises the building. LT2 training raises the comfortable floor. For Hyrox, you need both:
- **VO2max** gives you the ceiling so that race pace represents a manageable percentage of capacity
- **LT2** gives you the sustainable pace that allows consistent running between stations

**Weekly integration:**

| Day | Session | Target |
|---|---|---|
| Monday | Easy run + HIIT | Zone 2 + Hyrox-specific |
| Wednesday | Tempo run OR VO2max intervals (alternate weeks) | LT2 or VO2max |
| Other days | Easy runs, HIIT, strength | Supporting adaptations |

Alternating tempo and interval weeks ensures you develop both thresholds without overloading either system. Over 16 weeks, you get approximately 8 LT2 sessions and 8 VO2max sessions — enough for meaningful improvement in both.

Don't pick one over the other. Hyrox demands both: the ceiling (VO2max) and the sustainable floor (LT2). Build the tallest building possible, then live as high in it as you can.

How much water should I be drinking daily? I'm 82kg training for Hyrox. I feel like I'm always either dehydrated or peeing every 20 minutes.

That seesaw between dehydration and overhydration tells me you're probably slamming large volumes at random times instead of sipping strategically. Let me give you the framework.

**Baseline Daily Fluid Intake (excluding exercise):**

The evidence-based starting point is **30-40 ml per kg of body weight per day**. At 82 kg: **2.5-3.3 litres/day** of baseline fluid. On training days with exercise losses, your total will be **4.0-5.0+ litres/day**.

**How to assess if you're hydrated — four methods:**

| Method | Target | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| **Urine colour** | Pale straw / light yellow | First void of the day is most indicative |
| **Body weight** | Less than 1% change AM-to-AM | Weigh upon waking after voiding |
| **Thirst** | Not thirsty upon waking | Simple but valid in most athletes |
| **Urine frequency** | Every 2-4 hours during waking | Per ACSM guidelines |

**If your urine is clear**, you're likely overhydrating — and that's not harmless. Excess fluid can dilute sodium levels (hyponatremia) and just means your kidneys are working overtime to dump the excess. **Pale straw is the target**, not clear.

**Your daily hydration schedule:**

| Time | Action | Volume |
|---|---|---|
| Wake (6:00 AM) | Water upon rising | 500 ml |
| With breakfast | Sip steadily | 250-400 ml |
| Mid-morning to lunch | Steady sipping | 500-750 ml |
| Afternoon | Steady sipping | 500-750 ml |
| Evening (taper before bed) | Small sips with dinner | 400-500 ml |
| **Baseline total** | | **~2.5-3.0 L** |

**The key principle:** Distribute intake across the entire day. Your kidneys can process about 800 ml-1 L per hour. Drinking more than that in a short window just means you'll urinate most of it out. Sip, don't chug.

**When to add electrolytes vs plain water:**
- Sessions under 60 min in moderate conditions: **plain water** is fine
- Sessions over 60 min, high intensity, or hot/humid: use an **electrolyte drink** with 300-800 mg sodium per litre
- If you see white salt residue on your clothing after training, you're a heavy sodium sweater — prioritise sodium-containing drinks

I'm trying to get better at the sled pull but I keep running out of space in the athlete box. Like I'm pulling the rope but then I run out of room and have to stop and reset. Is there a better way?

You're hitting a very common issue. The athlete box is roughly **1.8 meters deep**, which means the walk-back method gives you only 2-3 steps before you hit the boundary line. If you're relying on walking backward as your primary technique, you're limited by the box dimensions. Let me restructure your approach.

**The solution: Combination Technique**

Instead of purely walking back, use this three-part pull cycle:

1. **Hip Extension (Primary Power):** Grab the rope with arms nearly fully extended. Explosively drive your hips backward — like a kettlebell swing or deadlift — while pulling through with your arms. This creates the most force per pull using your entire posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, lats).

2. **Arm Pull (Finish):** As the hip extension creates rope inertia, your arms finish the pull with a quick hand-over-hand motion. Short, choppy pulls — NOT long sweeping arm movements.

3. **Small Backward Steps (Assist):** Take 1-2 small steps backward during the hip extension to gain extra distance per pull cycle. This keeps you within the box.

**The rhythm:** Hip snap + arm pull + small step back. Reset. Repeat. Each cycle should move the sled about 0.5-1.0m. Over 12.5m, that's 13-25 pull cycles.

**Key rule:** Never step on the solid white line at the back of the athlete box — that's a penalty. Stay aware of your position.

**Rope management:** As you pull, the rope piles up around you. Guide it to one side (your non-dominant side) so it doesn't tangle your feet. This is critical — tripping on the rope is a common race-day disaster.

What weight are you pulling and what's your current time for the full 50m?

Men's Open — 103kg. My time last race was 6:30 which I know is pretty bad. I think the rope pile issue is real too, I got tangled twice. I also don't really know how to use my hips on the pull — when I try it feels awkward.

6:30 with tangles puts you in the beginner range (average male finisher is ~6:12), but the good news is I see at least 90-120 seconds of improvement from technique alone — no fitness changes needed.

**Fixing the Hip Extension (your biggest lever):**

The hip extension on a sled pull is the same movement pattern as a kettlebell swing. If you can swing a kettlebell, you can do this. Here's the drill progression:

**Week 1-2: Build the Pattern**
- **Drill A:** Russian kettlebell swings, 4 x 15 reps with a 24-32kg bell. Focus on the explosive hip snap. Your arms don't lift the bell — your hips launch it.
- **Drill B:** Without a sled, attach a resistance band to a post at ground level. Stand facing it, grab the band, extend arms, then explosively drive hips back while pulling the band. This IS the sled pull motion. 5 x 10 reps, 60 sec rest.

**Week 3-4: Apply to the Sled**
- Light weight (50-60kg), 5 x 12.5m. On each pull: grab rope with extended arms, then **think "kettlebell swing."** Your hips drive back, your body weight shifts backward, and the rope comes with you. Arms just guide and finish.
- Tempo: rapid, choppy pulls. **Never let the sled stop.** Static friction is dramatically higher than kinetic friction — once the sled stops, it takes much more force to restart.

**Fixing the Rope Tangle:**
- **Practice in a taped-off box.** Mark 1.8m x 1.0m on the floor with tape. Pull your full 12.5m distance within this box. Every session.
- **Rope management rule:** As you pull each section, guide the rope to fall to your LEFT (if right-handed). Step to the right of the pile. Consistent, deliberate placement.
- **Pre-pull:** Before your first pull, take all the slack out of the rope. Tension it so pull #1 actually moves the sled.

**Week 5-6:** Race weight (103kg) + 35kg (carpet simulation) = 138kg. 4 x 12.5m, 90 sec rest. Full combination technique with rope management.

**Week 7-8:** Full 50m at race weight + 35kg. Then 50m at race weight (it'll feel light). Add 1km run before to simulate race fatigue.

**Always use chalk.** It's permitted and makes a significant difference, especially after 3 stations of accumulated sweat. Target time: **sub-5:00** in 8 weeks (a 90-second improvement).

**Galpin's Endurance Hierarchy (from Huberman Lab Episode 3):**

| Type | Work Duration | Fuel Source | HR Zone | RPE | Breathing |
|------|-------------|------------|---------|-----|----------|
| Muscular Endurance | Repeated reps to local failure | Glycogen, PCr | Variable | 6-8/10 | Unrestricted |
| Anaerobic Capacity | 20-120 sec max effort | Glycogen (anaerobic) | Zone 4-5 | 9-10/10 | Forced |
| Max Aerobic (VO2max) | 4-8 min intervals | Glycogen + Oxidative | Zone 4-5 | 8-9/10 | Labored |
| Long-Duration Endurance | 15-60+ min continuous | Fat (primary) | Zone 2 | 4-6/10 | Nasal only |

Galpin classifies adaptations and tells you which training variables (volume, intensity, rest) drive each one. He's the scientist giving you the blueprint.

**Hinshaw's Approach:**
Hinshaw takes those same adaptations and builds **specific interval prescriptions** with exact distances, rest periods, and set structures. He's the practitioner who hands you the workout card.

- Both agree Zone 2 is the foundation (Galpin: "15+ min continuous at nasal breathing pace"; Hinshaw: "building the engine")
- Both identify VO2max intervals (4-8 min domain) as the highest-yield interval type
- Both emphasize that aerobic capacity is undertrained in functional fitness athletes

- **Galpin** tells you to train muscular endurance with "high reps, short rest, local fatigue" → **Hinshaw** gives you the wall ball EMOM with 20 reps + 5 air squats per minute

I had a bad training week — missed sessions, didn't sleep well, and felt terrible. Should I try to make up the missed workouts next week?

**No. Do not try to make up missed workouts.** This is one of the most common mistakes athletes make, and it almost always makes things worse. Here's why.

**The Compounding Problem:**
You had a bad week because of poor recovery (bad sleep, feeling terrible). If you now try to cram this week's training PLUS last week's missed sessions into the next 7 days, you're:
1. Starting from a recovery deficit (your body hasn't absorbed last week's training)
2. Adding MORE stress on top of incomplete recovery
3. Dramatically increasing injury risk
4. Almost guaranteeing you'll need a THIRD recovery week

**What to do instead:**

**This week — Reset, don't replay:**

1. **Accept the missed sessions as rest your body clearly needed.** The bad sleep and terrible feeling were signals that you were under-recovered. Your body used the missed sessions as an unplanned deload.

2. **Resume your NORMAL planned training this week** — not an augmented version. If your normal week is 5 sessions, do 5 sessions. Not 7 or 8.

3. **Start the week with an easy day** (Zone 2 run or active recovery) to assess your readiness before jumping into anything intense.

4. **Check your readiness markers before your first hard session:**
   - Morning RHR: within 3 bpm of baseline? → Good to go
   - HRV: within normal range? → Good to go
   - Slept 7+ hours? → Good to go
   - Motivation 6+/10? → Good to go
   - If 2+ markers are off → another easy day

**The Bigger Picture:**
Missing one week of training has a negligible impact on your Hyrox performance. Fitness adaptations don't evaporate in 7 days. Research shows:
- VO2max is maintained for 2-3 weeks without training
- Strength is maintained for 2-4 weeks
- Muscular endurance decreases faster but recovers quickly once training resumes

**What DOES hurt your Hyrox performance:**
- Overreaching from trying to "make up" missed work
- An injury from cramming 10 sessions into 7 days
- The psychological spiral of guilt → overtraining → more missed sessions

**The rule:** Last week is gone. This week is what you control. Train normally, recover properly, move forward. One bad week in a 16-week block is statistically insignificant.

My marathon training group says Hyrox is easy compared to a marathon. They keep telling me I'm overtraining for it.

Your marathon friends have earned the right to that opinion — finishing a marathon is a serious endurance achievement, and I wouldn't diminish that. They know what sustained suffering feels like over 3-5 hours, and that's a mental and physical toughness that absolutely transfers.

But "easy compared to a marathon" reflects a misunderstanding of what Hyrox actually tests. They're genuinely different challenges, and comparing them directly is a bit like comparing a decathlon to a 10,000m track race — both are hard, but they stress the body in fundamentally different ways.

**What a marathon tests:**
- Sustained aerobic capacity over 3-5 hours at a relatively steady output
- Glycogen management and fueling strategy
- Running economy and biomechanical efficiency over 42.2km
- Mental endurance through monotonous effort

**What Hyrox tests:**
- The ability to maintain running performance while accumulating muscular fatigue across 8 different movement patterns
- Repeated transitions between aerobic (running) and glycolytic (stations) energy systems
- Grip endurance across multiple stations (sled pull, farmers carry, wall balls)
- Power output under fatigue — pushing a 152kg sled after 4km of running and 3 prior stations
- Pacing across 16 discrete segments rather than one continuous effort

**The reality many marathon runners discover:**
- Running 8x1km in Hyrox sounds easy — until your quads are destroyed from sled push and your heart rate is 175 between stations. Many marathon runners post their slowest-ever per-km paces on Runs 6-8 of a Hyrox.
- Wall balls at Station 8 are a uniquely humbling experience for runners who have strong aerobic engines but limited upper body and squat endurance.
- The sled stations are often where marathon runners struggle most — they haven't trained for high-force, short-duration efforts.

**Conversely, many Hyrox athletes couldn't finish a marathon** — they lack the sustained aerobic base, the fueling experience, and the joint resilience for 42km of continuous running.

Neither event is "easy." They test different capacities. And as for overtraining — if you're specifically preparing for Hyrox, then Hyrox-specific training is by definition appropriate training. You're not overtraining; you're training for the event you signed up for. Respect both events, prepare specifically for yours.

What are the warning signs of overtraining and how do I distinguish it from just being tired?

This is one of the most important questions in training science. The distinction between productive fatigue and overtraining exists on a spectrum, and catching it early is everything.

**The Spectrum (European College of Sport Science definitions):**

| Stage | Performance Recovery | Timeline | Outcome |
|-------|---------------------|----------|---------|
| **Functional Overreaching (FO)** | Days to ~2 weeks | Short-term | POSITIVE — supercompensation after rest |
| **Non-Functional Overreaching (NFO)** | Weeks to months | Extended | NEGATIVE — lost training time, neuroendocrine symptoms |
| **Overtraining Syndrome (OTS)** | Months to >1 year | Prolonged | SEVERELY negative — maladapted HPA axis, systemic inflammation |

The critical insight: you can only distinguish NFO from OTS *retrospectively* based on recovery time (Kreher & Schwartz, 2012). Lifetime NFO prevalence in elite runners is ~60%. OTS is rare but devastating.

**Normal Fatigue vs. Warning Signs:**

| Marker | Normal (Just Tired) | Concerning (Overreaching) | Red Flag (Seek Rest) |
|--------|--------------------|--------------------------|-----------------------|
| Performance | ±2-3% day-to-day | >5% decline for 2+ weeks | Can't complete warm-up sets |
| Resting HR | ±3 bpm daily | 5+ bpm above 7-day avg for 3+ days | 8+ bpm above baseline |
| HRV | ±5-10% daily | >1 SD below 7-day mean for 3-4 days | >1.5 SD below for 3+ days |
| Sleep | Occasional bad night | <6 hrs for 3+ nights, efficiency <75% | Chronic insomnia despite fatigue |
| Mood | Normal fluctuation | Persistent negative mood for 5+ days | Apathy, dread of training |
| Soreness | 24-48 hr DOMS | Soreness 4/10+ lasting >72 hrs | Systemic soreness everywhere |
| Session quality | Can start and finish | Start but can't finish | Can't start at expected intensity |

**Decision Framework:**

**PUSH THROUGH when ALL of these are true:**
- HRV within 1 SD of rolling mean
- Resting HR within 3 bpm of baseline
- Motivation 6/10 or better
- Soreness 3/10 or less, localized
- Sleep was 7+ hours
- Warm-up performance within 5% of expected

**BACK OFF when 2+ of these are true:**
- HRV depressed >1 SD for 2+ days
- RHR elevated 5+ bpm for 2+ days
- Motivation 4/10 or below
- Systemic soreness >72 hours post-training
- Sleep <6 hours or severely disrupted

**MANDATORY REST when ANY 1 is true:**
- Signs of illness (sore throat, fever, swollen glands)
- RHR 8+ bpm above baseline
- Unable to complete warm-up at expected intensity
- 3+ warning signs present for 3+ consecutive days

The difference between a tough week and overtraining comes down to recovery timeline. If 2-3 easy days restore performance, it was functional overreaching — which is actually beneficial. If performance doesn't bounce back after a week of reduced training, you've crossed into NFO territory and need a full reactive deload.

**Root Cause 1: Aggressive first-half pacing (most likely primary cause)**

If your first 5 runs were at sub-4:30/km pace and your stations were fast, you were running above sustainable intensity for the full race duration. Brandt et al. (2025) shows that 79.5% of Hyrox race time is spent above 80% HRmax. If you were at 88-90% HRmax for the first half, you've burned through glycogen at an accelerated rate and accumulated a lactate debt you can never fully repay.

The math: at 90% HRmax, glycogen burn rate is approximately 3-4g per minute. Over the first 40 minutes, that's 120-160g of glycogen — roughly 30-40% of your total stores. Without adequate replenishment, you hit the wall at Station 6-7.

**Evidence check:** Were your first 5 runs faster than your training paces? Were your first 3 station times faster than your simulation benchmarks? If yes, you went out too fast.

**Root Cause 2: Inadequate intra-race fueling**

What did you eat and drink during the race? Most athletes who bonk at wall balls took zero or one gel during the race. For a sub-1:20 pace (75-80 minutes), you need 30-60g of carbohydrate per hour — that's 40-80g total. If you took nothing, your blood glucose crashed alongside your glycogen stores.

**The fix for fueling:**
- Gel 1: After Station 2 (sled push), during Run 3 — 25g carbs
- Gel 2: After Station 5 (rowing), during Run 6 — 25g carbs
- Sip of electrolyte drink at every available aid station
- Total intra-race carbs: 50-65g. This should be non-negotiable.

**Root Cause 3: Insufficient simulation training**

Did you ever complete a full race simulation at race weight and race pace during training? If your longest simulation was 6 stations or 60 minutes, you never trained your body to sustain effort at the 70-80 minute mark. The physical and metabolic demands of minutes 65-80 are drastically different from minutes 1-40 due to cumulative glycogen depletion, lactate accumulation, and neuromuscular fatigue.

**Root Cause 4: Pre-race carb loading may have been insufficient**

Full glycogen stores hold ~400-500g of glycogen (~1,600-2,000 kcal of readily available fuel). If you didn't carb-load properly (8-12 g/kg for 2-3 days pre-race), you may have started with partially filled stores. Combined with aggressive pacing and poor intra-race fueling, the tank ran dry at Station 6.

**Training (next 12-16 week block):**
1. Complete at least 3 full race simulations (not half-sims, FULL). Time every station and every run.
2. Practice negative-split pacing: deliberately run the first 4 runs 10-15 sec/km slower than your target average. Speed up in runs 5-8.
3. Train wall balls in a fatigued state: always do wall balls LAST in simulation sessions, after lunges and a run. This is the race sequence.
4. Add one 90-minute Zone 2 session per week to build the metabolic endurance for the full race duration.

**Nutrition (race preparation):**
1. **3 days pre-race:** Carb load at 8-12 g/kg. For an 82kg athlete, that's 656-984g of carbs per day. Yes, it's a lot. Eat it.
2. **Race morning:** 1-4 g/kg carbs 3-4 hours before. 60-80g 90 min before.
3. **During race:** 2 gels minimum, plus electrolyte drink. Practice this exact protocol in your simulations.
4. **Caffeine:** 3-4 mg/kg, 60-90 minutes pre-race. Reduces perceived exertion by 5-6%.

| Run | Old Strategy (failed) | New Strategy |
|---|---|---|
| Runs 1-3 | Sub-4:30/km (too fast) | 4:40-4:50/km (controlled) |
| Runs 4-5 | 4:30-4:40/km | 4:40-4:45/km |
| Runs 6-7 | 5:00-5:15/km (blowing up) | 4:35-4:45/km (consistent) |
| Run 8 | 5:30+/km (survival mode) | 4:30-4:40/km (strong finish) |

**The lesson:** Hyrox races are won in the second half. My grip always fails on the farmer carry. What grip technique should I use? And should I plan for breaks?

Grip failure on farmer carry is almost never just a grip problem — it's usually a combination of accumulated fatigue from prior stations (especially sled pull), poor shoulder posture, and a grip strategy that starts too aggressive. Let me fix all three.

**Grip Technique:**

1. **Use chalk if permitted.** This is non-negotiable. Sweaty hands after 6 runs and 5 stations make the kettlebell handles slippery. Chalk alone can add 30-50m to your unbroken carry distance.

2. **Full hand wrap, not fingertip grip.** Get the handle deep into your palm, wrap all four fingers completely around, and lock your thumb over your index finger. A fingertip grip engages the small finger flexors that fatigue quickly. A full palm grip distributes the load across the entire hand.

3. **Grip tight from the start — but not maximum.** Start at about **70-80% of your max squeeze.** This sounds counterintuitive — shouldn't you save grip for later? No. If you start too loose, the kettlebells shift and bounce, which creates unpredictable loads that spike forearm fatigue. A firm initial grip keeps the bells stable and reduces the total grip work over 200m. Gradually increase squeeze as fatigue builds — you're ramping from 70% to 100% rather than starting at 100% with nowhere to go.

4. **Shoulders packed.** Pull your shoulders down and back — retracted and depressed. This is critical because when your shoulders round forward and elevate (shrugging), the kettlebells hang in a biomechanically disadvantaged position and grip fatigue accelerates exponentially. Dr. Adam Storey calls this a "postural endurance test" more than a grip test.

**Break Strategy:**

For Men's Open (2x24kg), here's what I recommend based on your carry capacity:

| Carry Capacity | Strategy |
|---|---|
| Can carry 200m unbroken in training | Go unbroken on race day. You have a margin. |
| Can carry 150-200m in training | Plan ONE break at 100m. Brief 3-5 second reset — set down, shake hands, re-chalk if available, pick up. |
| Can carry 100-150m in training | Plan TWO breaks at ~70m and ~140m. Same 3-5 second protocol. |
| Under 100m in training | Three planned breaks at 50m intervals. Priority is building carry capacity in training. |

**The Break Protocol (When You Do Stop):**
- Set kettlebells down deliberately — don't drop them
- Shake your hands vigorously for 2-3 seconds
- Re-apply chalk if you have it
- Take 1-2 breaths
- Pick up and GO. Total break: **3-5 seconds maximum**

**Critical principle:** A planned 5-second break at the halfway mark is FAR better than carrying to grip failure at 160m and then needing a 20-30 second recovery. If you feel your grip moving from "manageable" to "about to fail," set down IMMEDIATELY. Don't push to failure.

**Downstream consideration:** After farmer carry, you still have sandbag lunges (where dropping the bag = 5-second penalty, second drop = DQ) and 100 wall balls. Manage grip fatigue as a resource that must last through three more tasks, not just this one.

I'm a CrossFit athlete running 35 miles a week now for Hyrox prep. How should I distribute my running intensity? I feel like I'm always in the middle — not easy, not hard.

You've described the classic "gray zone" problem — and at 35 miles per week, this is the most important thing to fix in your training right now. The research is unequivocal on this.

**The Science**

The polarized training model (80% easy / 20% hard) consistently outperforms all other intensity distributions:

- **Seiler & Kjerland (2006)**: World and Olympic Champion endurance athletes spend 75-80% of training time at low intensity, despite racing at much higher intensities
- **Helgerud et al. (2007)**: 4x4-minute intervals at 90-95% max HR produced **10.8% VO2 max improvement** vs only 3.5% for long slow distance — nearly 3x the improvement
- **Stöggl & Sperlich (2014)**: After 9 weeks, the polarized group showed superior improvements in 10K time, VO2 max, running economy, AND lactate threshold vs threshold-only training. The threshold group actually DECLINED in some metrics.

**Your 35 MPW Distribution Should Be:**

| Zone | Miles | Percentage | Effort Level |
|------|-------|-----------|-------------|
| Zone 1-2 (Easy) | 28-30 miles | 80-85% | Full conversation, nose breathing possible |
| Zone 4-5 (Hard) | 5-7 miles | 15-20% | Short sentences, labored breathing |
| Zone 3 (Gray Zone) | 0 miles | 0% | **Eliminate this entirely** |

**Critical for Hyrox Athletes**: Your Hyrox station work (sled push, wall balls, rowing intervals) **counts in the 20% hard bucket**. If you're doing 2-3 hard station sessions per week, you may only need 1-2 hard running sessions. The rest of your running must be genuinely easy.

**Your Restructured Running Week**

| Run | Day | Miles | Zone | Purpose |
|-----|-----|-------|------|---------|
| Easy 1 | Mon | 5 mi | Zone 2 | Recovery + volume accumulation |
| Tempo | Wed | 6 mi | 2 mi easy → 2.5 mi @ 75-85% HR → 1.5 mi easy | Lactate threshold development |
| Easy 2 | Thu | 4 mi | Zone 2 | Recovery from tempo |
| Intervals | Fri | 6 mi | 1.5 mi warm-up → 4x4 min @ 90-95% HR w/ 3 min jog → 1.5 mi cool-down | VO2 max (the "magic protocol") |
| Easy 3 | Sat | 5 mi | Zone 2 | Can combine with Hyrox simulation |
| Long | Sun | 9 mi | Zone 2 | Aerobic infrastructure |
| **Total** | | **35 mi** | **Easy: 23 mi (66%) / Hard: 12 mi (34%)** | |

**Wait — 66/34 isn't 80/20!**

Correct. That's because you also do Hyrox station work 2-3x/week, which IS high intensity. When you add those sessions to the "hard" bucket:

- Running hard: 12 miles (~2 hours)
- Station hard: ~2-3 hours of high-intensity work
- Running easy: 23 miles (~3.5 hours)
- Total hard: ~4-5 hours / Total easy: ~3.5 hours + warm-ups/cool-downs

The overall ratio becomes approximately **70/30 to 75/25** when including all training modalities — which is within the range that Seiler's research shows elite athletes actually operate in.

**The Practical Fix**

For your easy runs, your perceived effort should feel **embarrassingly slow**. If someone passed you on the trail, you'd be self-conscious about your pace. That's the right effort level. Use a heart rate monitor — stay below 70% of max HR (or 65% of HRR). If you drift above that, walk for 30 seconds and resume.

The payoff: within 4-6 weeks, your hard sessions will get FASTER because you're actually recovering between them. And your late-race Hyrox running splits will improve because your aerobic base — built on all those easy miles — supports sustained output when everything else is fatigued.

Can you explain the RPE scale you use and how I should rate my effort during training?

I use the Borg CR-10 RPE scale — it's the gold standard validated by Zourdos et al. (2016) for resistance training and Foster et al. (2001) for endurance work. Here's exactly how it breaks down:

| RPE | Description | What It Feels Like |
|-----|-------------|--------------------|
| **1-2** | Very light | Walking pace, barely feels like exercise |
| **3-4** | Light to moderate | Conversational effort, Zone 2 running |
| **5-6** | Moderate to hard | Tempo pace, can speak in short sentences |
| **7-8** | Hard to very hard | Threshold effort, 2-3 word answers max |
| **9** | Near maximal | Could do 1 more rep or 30 more seconds |
| **10** | Maximal | Absolute limit, nothing left |

**How to use it in practice:** I collect RPE at three points every session. First, after your warm-up — if the warm-up feels like RPE 7 when it should be 3-4, something is off and we adjust immediately. Second, at the midpoint — this tells me if we're tracking to the target or need to modify. Third, 15-30 minutes post-session — this gives me your Session RPE (sRPE), which I multiply by session duration to calculate your training load in Arbitrary Units.

**The key mistake athletes make:** Rating everything 7 or 8. If every session feels the same intensity, your RPE calibration is off. Zone 2 runs should genuinely feel like a 3-4. HIIT intervals should hit 8-9. If you can't distinguish between those, we need to recalibrate your internal gauge. Pay attention to breathing rate, ability to talk, and muscle burn — those are your anchors.

I want a phosphagen power session — short sprints that develop explosive power for sled push starts. Something efficient, under 15 minutes total.

Phosphagen training is the most underrated component of Hyrox prep. Your sled push time is largely determined by how explosively you initiate each 12.5m length. Here's how we train that.

**Phosphagen Power Sprints — 8 Rounds:**
- 10 sec: All-Out Assault Bike Sprint
- 50 sec: Complete Rest (stand, walk, shake legs)

**Total session time:** 8 minutes. Record peak watts every round.

**Intensity:** 95-100%. Every sprint is absolute max effort.

**Why 10:50 (1:5 work:rest):**
- The phosphagen system provides immediate energy for 5-15 seconds of max effort. After 10 seconds, ATP stores are significantly depleted.
- 50 seconds allows ~85-90% phosphagen recovery. Full recovery takes 3-5 minutes, but 50 seconds is enough to repeat near-maximal output.
- If we shortened rest to 30 seconds (1:3), you'd start relying on the glycolytic system — different session, different purpose.

**Why the Assault Bike:**
- Safe for absolute max-effort sprints — no eccentric loading, no technique breakdown.
- Full body engagement — arms and legs, similar to sled push explosive demands.
- Watts are a precise, repeatable metric.

**Quality check:** Track peak watts each round. If watts drop more than 15% from round 1, the session is no longer training phosphagen — you're drifting glycolytic. Stop or extend rest to 60 seconds.

**Example:** Round 1: 850W. Below 722W (850 x 0.85) = time to stop.

**Progression:**
- Week 1: 6 rounds, 10 sec / 50 sec
- Week 2: 8 rounds, 10 sec / 50 sec
- Week 3: 8 rounds, 12 sec / 48 sec
- Week 4: 10 rounds, 12 sec / 48 sec

**Timing:** Early in session, after warm-up but BEFORE conditioning. Power training requires a fresh nervous system.

When should I do my Hyrox simulation workouts and what type should they be?

Simulations are your most valuable training sessions — and also the most fatiguing. Too many and you overtrain. Too few and you have no idea how station-to-station fatigue compounds. Here's the exact schedule:

| Week | Simulation | Type | Volume | Intensity |
|------|-----------|------|--------|----------|
| 4 (Deload) | Baseline Benchmark | Partial — 4 stations + 4 km | Moderate | 85% |
| 8 (Deload) | Half-Simulation | First half of race (Stations 1-4 + 4 km) | High | 90% |
| 10 | Full Simulation | Complete 8-station race rehearsal | Maximum | 90-95% |
| 12 (Deload) | Three-Quarter Sim | Second half (Stations 4-8 + 5 runs) | High | 88% |
| 14 | Dress Rehearsal | Abbreviated half — reduced volume | Low-moderate | 70-75% |

**Week 4 Baseline:** Four stations (SkiErg, Sled Push, Row, Wall Balls) with 1 km runs between each. Record every segment time. This is your measurement stick for the entire plan.

**Week 8 Half-Sim:** First-half race — SkiErg through BBJ with 4 km of running. Compare run splits and station times to your Week 4 baseline. Target: less than 15 sec/km pace degradation from Run 1 to Run 4.

**Week 10 Full Sim:** This is the big one. All 8 stations, all 8 km of running, 100% race weight. Target time: 68-72 minutes. Practice race-day nutrition during this — test gels, electrolytes, timing. Take a gel between BBJ and Run 5.

**Week 12 Three-Quarter Sim:** Focuses on the second half (BBJ through Wall Balls) because that's where most time is lost. There's a 0.738 correlation between lunge performance and wall ball performance — athletes who go quad-dominant on lunges average 75 seconds slower on wall balls. This sim teaches you to manage that connection.

**Week 14 Dress Rehearsal:** Half volume, full race weight. SkiErg 750 m, Sled Push 25 m, Wall Balls 50 reps with 1 km runs. RPE 6-7 max. If it doesn't feel easy, the taper is working.

Notice sims happen on deload weeks (4, 8, 12) or during taper (14). They replace training volume rather than stacking on top of it.

[CONTEXT] Athlete is a 40-year-old female, 62kg, racing Women's Open. Stats: 5K in 23:15, back squat 80kg. She has been training for 10 weeks and reports her sled push technique still feels awkward — she can't generate enough force and keeps getting stuck at the transitions between 12.5m lengths. She strength trains 3x/week but mostly upper body and isolation work.
I've been training for 10 weeks but sled push still feels awful. I get stuck between lengths and can't keep momentum. My gym says my squat is 80kg at 62kg bodyweight — is that enough?

Let me diagnose this from three angles: strength adequacy, technique, and training focus.

**Strength analysis:**

Women's Open sled push is 102kg total (including sled). At 62kg bodyweight and an 80kg squat, your squat-to-bodyweight ratio is 1.29x. That's modest but should be adequate for a 102kg sled — you're not trying to squat it, you're pushing it horizontally at ~30% of your vertical max force.

However, I notice your training is "mostly upper body and isolation work." This is a critical problem. Sled push is a LOWER BODY exercise. It's a horizontal force production movement driven by hip extension and knee extension — the same muscles as a squat and deadlift. If you're spending 3 strength sessions per week on bicep curls, lateral raises, and cable work, you're not building the force production capacity you need.

**The technique problem — getting stuck at transitions:**

The 12.5m sled push has a critical moment: the restart after each turn. You push 12.5m, the sled hits the wall/bumper, you reposition, and push back. The restart is where most athletes lose time because:
1. They lose their body angle (standing too upright)
2. They try to move the sled from a dead stop using upper body
3. Their foot position doesn't allow leg drive

**The technique fix:**

**Body angle:** Aim for 45 degrees or lower. The closer to horizontal your torso, the more of your force is directed into horizontal sled movement rather than wasted pushing downward. At 62kg, you need every newton directed forward.

**Restart protocol:** When the sled stops at the wall:
1. Keep your hands on the sled. Don't stand up.
2. Walk your feet in close to the sled.
3. Get your shoulders over or slightly in front of your hands.
4. Drive with your legs — think "push the floor away" not "push the sled forward."
5. Take 3-4 SHORT, explosive steps to get momentum, then transition to a steady cadence.

**Step cadence:** Short, quick steps. NOT long driving strides. Many athletes try to lunge-step the sled, which creates a stop-and-start pattern. Think "running in place" with aggressive forward lean.

**The training overhaul (remaining 6 weeks):**

Your strength program needs to shift dramatically:

**Eliminate or reduce:**
- Bicep curls, lateral raises, cable flyes, leg extensions, leg curls as primary exercises
- These are isolation movements that don't transfer to sled push

**Add immediately:**

| Exercise | Sets x Reps | Load | Frequency | Why |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Back Squat | 3 x 5 @ 75-80% | 60-64kg | 2x/week | Primary leg strength for sled push |
| Romanian Deadlift | 3 x 8 @ 70% | 45-50kg | 2x/week | Hip extension strength for sled drive |
| Walking Lunges (heavy) | 3 x 10/leg @ DBs | 2 x 15-20kg | 1x/week | Unilateral leg drive, lunge station transfer |
| Sled Push Practice | 4 x 12.5m @ 80% race weight (~82kg) | — | 2x/week | Motor pattern practice |
| Plank | 3 x 45 sec | — | 2x/week | Core bracing for force transfer |

**Why your squat matters more than you think:**

Your 80kg squat is 1.29x bodyweight. For Women's Open sled push (102kg), I'd want to see at least 1.3-1.5x bodyweight squat for comfortable performance. You're right at the threshold. Building your squat from 80 to 90kg over 6 weeks (achievable with 2x/week focused training) would give you a meaningful strength reserve that makes the sled feel lighter.

Galpin's 3-to-5 rule for strength: 3-5 exercises, 3-5 reps, 3-5 sets, 3-5 min rest. Your squat sessions should use this framework.

**Nutrition to support the strength shift:**
- Protein at 2.0 g/kg = 124g/day (minimum). If you've been eating lower, this is a significant increase.
- Creatine at 5g/day — this directly supports the phosphagen system for sled push AND supports lean mass development.
- Don't cut calories while trying to build strength for sled push. Eat at maintenance minimum.

**The 6-week sled push improvement timeline:**
- Weeks 1-2: Technique focus at 80% race weight. 4 x 12.5m, 2x/week. Film and review.
- Weeks 3-4: Increase to 90% race weight. Add compromised running: sled push → 400m run after each set.
- Weeks 5-6: Full race weight (102kg). Time full 50m attempts. Practice restarts until they're automatic.

Your sled push isn't limited by fitness — it's limited by technique and leg strength training. Fix both and you'll see a 30-45 second improvement within 6 weeks.

How do I know if an improvement on a test is real progress or just noise? I got 50m more on the Cooper test but I'm not sure if that means anything.

50m on the Cooper test is **within the normal noise range** — I'd need to see it again before calling it real progress. Here's how to separate signal from noise across all your Hyrox metrics.

**The Noise Threshold for Key Tests:**

| Test | Meaningful Improvement | Normal Noise (Day-to-Day Variation) |
|------|----------------------|-------------------------------------|
| Cooper test (12 min) | **≥100m** | ±50m (weather, motivation, fatigue, caffeine, sleep) |
| 30-min time trial | **≥200m or ≥5 sec/km** | ±100m |
| Back squat 3RM | **≥5% increase** | ±2.5% (daily readiness, CNS state) |
| SkiErg 1000m | **≥5 sec** | ±3 sec |
| Wall balls 100 reps | **≥15 sec** | ±8 sec |
| Sled push 50m | **≥10 sec** | ±5 sec (surface friction, sled condition) |
| Zone 2 pace at fixed HR | **≥5 sec/km faster** | ±3 sec/km (temperature, hydration, sleep) |

**Your 50m Cooper Test Improvement:**
This falls within the ±50m noise range. It COULD be the beginning of real progress, but it could also be explained by:
- Better pacing (you learned from the first test)
- Better weather conditions (cooler temperature)
- More caffeine or better sleep
- Higher motivation

**The 2-Test Confirmation Rule:**
Require **≥2 consecutive tests** showing improvement in the same direction before concluding a real training effect. If your next Cooper test in 4-6 weeks shows another 50-100m improvement (so 100-150m total above baseline), THAT's a real signal.

**How to Minimize Test Noise:**
1. **Standardize conditions:** Same track/treadmill, same time of day, same warm-up protocol
2. **Control fueling:** Same pre-test meal and caffeine intake
3. **Test when fresh:** Not the day after a hard training block
4. **Same environmental conditions:** Temperature and wind can shift Cooper test results by 100m+
5. **Use 7-day rolling averages** for daily metrics (RHR, HRV, body weight)

**When to Worry About LACK of Progress:**
If you see <1% improvement in any primary metric for **3+ consecutive testing cycles** (12-18 weeks) despite consistent training, it's time for a stimulus change:
- Swap training modalities (replace steady runs with fartlek; replace standard strength with tempo work)
- Introduce a novel stressor (hill sprints, sled sprint intervals)
- If HRV/RHR show no suppression, you may be **undertrained, not overtrained** — increase training intensity by 10%

Keep testing at 50m. One more test will tell us if it's real.

Should I breathe through my nose or mouth during Hyrox?

It depends on the intensity, and the answer changes throughout the race.

**During runs — it depends on your zone:**
- **Zone 2 (easy effort):** Nasal breathing is ideal. It filters and humidifies air, promotes diaphragmatic breathing, and activates the parasympathetic nervous system — all of which help manage heart rate. If you can maintain nasal breathing during the 1km runs, you're at the right intensity for those segments.
- **Above Zone 2:** Once intensity increases, mouth breathing is natural and necessary. Don't fight it. Your body needs more oxygen throughput than your nasal passages can deliver. Trying to force nasal breathing at high intensity creates an oxygen deficit.

**At stations — mouth breathing is the default.** The metabolic demand of sled pushes, wall balls, and BBJs is too high for nasal breathing alone. Your body will naturally shift to mouth breathing, and you should let it. Trying to nasal-breathe during a sled push is fighting your physiology.

**The exception: Farmer Carry.** This is the one station where controlled nasal breathing — or at least calm, rhythmic breathing — can actually help. The farmer carry is lower intensity relative to other stations, and it's your best opportunity to bring heart rate down before the final two stations (sandbag lunges and wall balls). Breathe in through your nose for 3-4 steps, out through your mouth for 3-4 steps. If full nasal breathing isn't possible, even partial nasal inhales help.

**The practical rule:** Don't be dogmatic about nose vs. mouth. Use nasal breathing when the intensity allows it (easy runs, farmer carry) because it helps regulate heart rate. Switch to mouth breathing when intensity demands it (stations, hard runs). Your body is smarter than any breathing protocol — listen to it.

**One training hack:** Practice nasal-only running during your Zone 2 sessions. It's both a breathing exercise and a built-in intensity governor — if you can't maintain nasal breathing, you're running too hard for Zone 2.

I don't have a sled at my gym. How can I train for the Hyrox sled push?

No sled is a common problem, but there are effective alternatives. The sled push is primarily a **quad, glute, and calf exercise** performed at a 45-degree body angle with rapid short steps. Let me give you a program that builds the same movement patterns and energy systems.

**Primary Alternatives (pick 2 per week):**

**1. Prowler/Tire Push (Best Alternative)**
If your gym has ANY kind of push sled or even a heavy tire, use it. Load to approximate race weight (152kg for Men's Open). Remember: gym floors are smoother than Hyrox carpet, so add **20-35kg** to simulate race friction.

**2. Wall Push Drills**
Place hands on a wall at shoulder height, lean to 45 degrees, and drive rapid short steps in place for 30-60 seconds. This trains the exact body angle and stepping cadence. 5 x 45 seconds, 90 sec rest.

**3. Heavy Leg Press (Single-Leg Emphasis)**
Leg press at 120-150% bodyweight, 4 x 15 reps per leg, 90 sec rest. Mimics the quad/glute demand. Keep RPE at 7-8.

**4. Hill Sprints (Best Cardio Alternative)**
Find a moderate hill (8-12% grade). Sprint 30-50m maintaining a forward lean. Walk back. 8-10 reps. This replicates the body angle, leg drive, and cardiovascular demand.

**8-Week Program (2 sessions/week):**

| Week | Session A | Session B |
|---|---|---|
| 1-2 | Wall push drills 5x45s + leg press 4x15 | Hill sprints 8x30m |
| 3-4 | Wall push drills 5x60s + heavy goblet squats 4x12 | Hill sprints 8x40m |
| 5-6 | If possible, find a sled for 2 sessions. Race weight, 4x12.5m | Hill sprints 6x50m + heavy step-ups 4x10/leg |
| 7-8 | Sled at race weight (borrow, rent, find a CrossFit box) | 500m run → hill sprint → 500m run (race sim) |

**Key Strength Exercises to Add:**
- **Front squats:** 4 x 6 at RPE 8 (quad dominant, upright torso)
- **Walking lunges with forward lean:** 3 x 20 steps (mimics push angle)
- **Calf raises:** 3 x 20 (calf endurance for rapid stepping)
- **Plank holds:** 3 x 45 sec (core anti-extension, same as sled push)

**Critical advice:** You MUST get at least 3-4 real sled push sessions before race day. Find a CrossFit box, rent time at a Hyrox training facility, or find a gym with a sled. No substitute perfectly replicates the sled push, and the Hyrox carpet feel is something you need to experience in advance.

During wall balls, I notice I can't get deep enough in the squat. My heels come up and I lean forward a lot. Is this a mobility issue or a strength issue?

Based on what you're describing — heels rising and forward lean during wall ball squats — this is almost certainly an **ankle dorsiflexion limitation**, not a strength issue. Here's how to confirm and fix it.

**Quick Diagnostic Test:**
Stand facing a wall. Place your front foot 10 cm (about 4 inches) from the wall. Keeping your heel flat on the ground, try to touch your knee to the wall by bending your ankle. If you can't touch the wall without your heel lifting, your dorsiflexion is restricted below the 35-degree minimum needed for a deep squat.

Normal range: Knee should reach the wall at 10-12 cm distance. Good range: 12-15 cm. Excellent: 15+ cm.

**Why this matters for Hyrox:**

Restricted ankle dorsiflexion (<35 degrees) forces three compensations during wall balls:
1. **Heel rise** — shifts balance forward, reduces squat depth, wastes energy on calf tension
2. **Excessive forward torso lean** — puts more stress on the lower back, reduces the efficiency of the upward throw
3. **Reduced squat depth** — you don't get the full elastic stretch-shortening cycle in your quads and glutes, so each rep requires more muscular effort

Over 100 reps, these compensations add up to significant energy waste and slower completion time.

**It also affects:**
- Sandbag lunges (limits step length, causes heel rise)
- Sled push (limits ankle range in the push position)
- Running (reduces push-off power and stride efficiency)

Try the wall test today and tell me how far you get. That'll determine how aggressive the mobility protocol needs to be.
Just tried it — I can only get about 6 cm from the wall before my heel lifts. That seems pretty bad. What do I do to fix this?

6 cm is significantly restricted — that confirms your wall ball issue is mobility-driven, not strength-driven. The good news: ankle dorsiflexion responds well to consistent mobilization. Here's your protocol.

**Daily Ankle Mobilization Protocol (5-7 min, every single day):**

**Exercise 1: Wall Ankle Dorsiflexion Mobilization**
- 10 reps per side, 2-second hold at end range
- Start at your current max (6 cm from wall)
- Drive knee forward over toes toward wall, keeping heel GLUED to floor
- Each week, try to move foot 1 cm further from wall
- Target: 12 cm in 6-8 weeks

**Exercise 2: Banded Ankle Mobilization**
- Loop a resistance band around a rig at ankle height
- Step into band so it wraps around the front of your ankle joint (the "crease")
- Step away to create tension — the band pulls the talus bone posteriorly (where it needs to go for dorsiflexion)
- Lunge forward, driving knee over toes
- 15 reps per side, 2-second holds
- This is the single most effective ankle mobility drill — the band creates joint space

**Exercise 3: Elevated Heel Calf Stretch**
- Stand on a step with heels hanging off
- Drop heels below the level of the step
- Hold for 30 seconds, 3 reps per side
- This targets the gastrocnemius and soleus (the muscles limiting dorsiflexion)

**Exercise 4: Deep Goblet Squat Hold**
- Hold a light dumbbell at chest, sink into the deepest squat possible
- Elbows press knees out, actively drive knees over toes
- 2 x 30 seconds
- This integrates ankle mobility with the exact position you need for wall balls

**Pre-Workout Ankle Activation (add before any session with wall balls, lunges, or squats):**
- 10 x wall ankle mobilizations per side
- 10 x bodyweight squats with 3-second pause at the bottom, actively pressing knees forward

**Interim Fix While Building Mobility:**
- Squat on 5 lb plates or small wedges under your heels during wall balls in training
- This artificially creates the dorsiflexion your ankles can't yet provide
- Use this as a crutch during training while the daily mobility work builds real range
- Wean off the heel elevation over 4-6 weeks as mobility improves

**Expected Timeline:**
- Week 2: 7-8 cm on wall test (+1-2 cm)
- Week 4: 9-10 cm (+3-4 cm) — you'll start feeling a difference in wall balls
- Week 6-8: 11-12 cm (+5-6 cm) — functional range for uncompensated deep squats
- Week 8+: 12+ cm — no longer a limiter

**The non-negotiable:** This must be DAILY. Ankle mobility is stubborn — 3x/week won't cut it. 5 minutes every single day for 6-8 weeks. Set a phone reminder. Once you hit 12 cm, you can reduce to 3x/week for maintenance.

When this clicks, your wall ball time will drop noticeably — you'll get deeper squats with less effort, better power transfer on the throw, and more efficient reps.

- You're wrecked for Run 5 (which you may end up walking)

- Step-up: 4 sec/rep but needs only 10 sec of total rest = ~4:00 working + 0:10 resting = ~6:30-7:00

You're right — there are multiple zone systems and it creates confusion. Here's the one I use for Hyrox athletes, based on the 5-zone model anchored to physiological thresholds.

**The 5-Zone Model (% of Max Heart Rate):**

| Zone | % HRmax | Name | Feel | Breathing | Hyrox Use |
|------|---------|------|------|-----------|----------|
| 1 | 50-60% | Recovery | Very easy, walking pace | Nose only, effortless | Active recovery days, post-station walks |
| 2 | 60-70% | Aerobic Base | Easy, conversational | Nose only, slight effort | Easy runs, base building (3-4x/week) |
| 3 | 70-80% | Tempo | Moderate, "comfortably hard" | Mouth breathing begins | Tempo runs, progressive runs |
| 4 | 80-90% | Threshold | Hard, can speak in phrases only | Labored, rhythmic | Threshold repeats, 1 km race pace |
| 5 | 90-100% | VO2max/Anaerobic | Very hard to maximal | Gasping, forced | Norwegian 4x4, 30/30 intervals, station efforts |

**How to find YOUR zones:**

**Method 1: Max HR Test (most practical)**
- Warm up 15 minutes, then run 3 x 3-min hill repeats at increasing intensity (moderate, hard, all-out). The peak HR in the final rep is approximately your HRmax
- Common estimate: 220 - age is UNRELIABLE (standard deviation of ±10-12 bpm). A field test is always better

**Method 2: Threshold-Based (most accurate without a lab)**
- Run a 30-minute time trial at the fastest sustainable pace
- Average HR during the final 20 minutes = your lactate threshold heart rate (LTHR)
- Zone 2 ceiling = 68-83% of LTHR
- Zone 4 = 95-105% of LTHR

**How Hyrox race data maps to zones:**
The Brandt et al. (2025) study showed:
- Average race HR: 170.9 bpm (Zone 4-5 for most athletes)
- 79.5% of race time spent above 80% HRmax (Zone 4+)
- Station HR averaged 173.7 bpm (higher than runs at 168.9 bpm)

**Training zone distribution for Hyrox (weekly):**

| Zone | % of Training Time | Sessions/Week |
|------|--------------------|---------------|
| Zone 1-2 | 75-80% | 3-4 easy runs/rides (45-80 min) |
| Zone 3 | 5-10% | Portions of progressive runs |
| Zone 4-5 | 15-20% | 1-2 interval sessions + station work |

This follows the polarized model: make easy days truly easy (Zone 1-2) and hard days truly hard (Zone 4-5). The middle ground (Zone 3) should be a small fraction of total volume — it creates fatigue without providing the stimulus for either base or top-end improvement.

How do I recover my breathing between stations and runs?

The transition zone — from station exit to the start of your next run — is the most overlooked opportunity in all of Hyrox. This is where smart athletes gain 30-60 seconds over the course of a race without running or working any harder.

**The Immediate Post-Station Protocol (first 15-30 seconds):**

As soon as you finish a station and start moving toward the run course, take **5-10 deep diaphragmatic breaths.** Here's the specific technique:

1. **Inhale through your nose for a 4-count** — fill your belly first, then your chest (diaphragmatic breathing, not chest breathing)
2. **Exhale through your mouth for a 4-count** — controlled, steady exhale, not a forceful blow
3. **Repeat 5-10 times** as you walk or slow-jog to the run start

This 4-count inhale, 4-count exhale pattern activates your **parasympathetic nervous system** — the body's "rest and digest" mode. It's the fastest physiological mechanism you have for lowering heart rate. Research shows that extended exhales in particular stimulate the vagus nerve, which directly slows heart rate.

**Why this works:** After a hard station, you're in sympathetic overdrive — fight or flight. Your heart rate is elevated, breathing is rapid and shallow, and stress hormones are flooding your system. The controlled breathing interrupts this cascade and begins shifting you back toward a recoverable state.

**The Transition-to-Run Protocol:**

- **Don't sprint into the run.** Start the first 100-200m at an easy jog — even slower than your target run pace. Let your breathing settle into a rhythmic pattern.
- **Match breathing to foot strikes.** A 3:3 pattern (inhale for 3 steps, exhale for 3 steps) works well for easy pace. As you build speed, shift to 3:2 or 2:2.
- **By 400m into the run,** you should be at your target pace with controlled, rhythmic breathing.

**Practice this in training:** After every station practice, immediately do the 5-10 breath protocol followed by a 1km run. Train the transition as deliberately as you train the stations themselves. On race day, this sequence should be automatic — not something you're trying to remember while gasping.

**Pro tip:** During the farmer carry specifically, use the entire 200m as active breathing recovery. It's the only station slow enough to genuinely recover your respiratory rate. Nail your breathing on the carry, and you'll arrive at sandbag lunges in much better shape.

- 24-min 5K → Your 1km splits will be ~4:48/km. After station work, expect those to balloon to 5:15-5:30/km. That's 42-44 minutes of running alone. Elite Hyrox men run their 8km in ~31 minutes.

1. **Cut strength training from 5 days to 2.** You don't need more strength. You need to maintain it while building endurance. Use Galpin's 3-to-5 rule: 3-5 exercises, 3-5 reps, 3-5 sets, 3-5 min rest. Heavy but low volume. Back squat 3x4 at 82%, deadlift 3x3 at 85%, done.

3. **Run 30-35 miles per week minimum.** I know that sounds like a lot coming from CrossFit. But Hyrox is fundamentally an endurance event with strength components, not the other way around. Start at 25 mpw and add 10% per week.

4. **Replace your metcons with Hyrox-specific HIIT.** Instead of random WODs, train compromised running — run 400m immediately after sled pushes, row 1000m then run 1km. This teaches your body to clear lactate while moving, which is the #1 skill in Hyrox transitions.

I'm a strong runner but my SkiErg and row times are terrible. Is this an energy system issue or a technique issue?

It's likely **both**, but the energy system component is what most athletes miss. Here's how to diagnose it.

Your SkiErg 1000m and Row 1000m are **3-5 minute efforts** demanding a blend of oxidative and glycolytic energy. If your running is strong, your oxidative base is solid. But running primarily trains your **lower body** aerobic capacity. Your upper body (lats, triceps, core) may have a **significantly underdeveloped aerobic infrastructure** — fewer capillaries, fewer mitochondria in those muscle groups.

Hinshaw identifies this critical gap: **every movement is unique, and every intensity within that movement is unique.** Aerobic capacity on the rower and SkiErg must be trained specifically — it doesn't fully transfer from running.

**Diagnosis test:**
1. Row 1000m at best effort. Record average HR for the last 2 minutes.
2. Run 1 km at a pace that produces the same HR.
3. If running feels moderate but the row felt maximal → upper body aerobic capacity is the limiter.

**The Fix — Hinshaw's Multi-Modal Transfer Protocol:**

**Session 1: Cross-Modal Aerobic Transfer (1x/week)**
- 4 rounds of: 2 min SkiErg + 2 min Row + 2 min Bike
- Moderate-hard pace, RPE 7/10
- Rest: 40 sec between efforts, 4 min between rounds

**Session 2: Machine-Specific Intervals (1x/week, alternate)**
- SkiErg week: 6 x 250m at goal race pace, 90 sec rest
- Row week: 4 x 500m at threshold pace, 2 min rest
- RPE: 8/10

**Session 3: Supplementary Pulling Work (2x/week)**
- Lat pulldowns: 3 x 12-15 at RPE 7
- Tricep dips: 3 x 12-15
- Prone rows: 3 x 10-12

**Technique quick wins** (free speed):
- **SkiErg:** Drive with the hips, not just arms. Hinge at hip, pull handles to thighs, snap hips forward.
- **Row:** Power sequence is legs-back-arms on the drive. Most people arm-pull first and lose 30% of power.

Give this 6-8 weeks. Expect 10-15% improvement on both machines.

I've been doing a lot of ice baths after every training session because I heard they help recovery. Is that actually helping or hurting my Hyrox prep?

Straight answer: daily ice baths are likely *hurting* your training adaptations. I know that's not what you want to hear, but the science is clear on this.

**The problem with chronic cold water immersion (CWI):**
Roberts et al. (2015) showed that regular ice baths after resistance training blunt muscle hypertrophy and strength gains. The mechanism is straightforward — the inflammation from training isn't the enemy. It's the *signal* that tells your body to adapt. Cold water suppresses that inflammatory cascade (reduces IL-6, TNF-alpha, and other cytokines), which also suppresses the downstream adaptation. You're essentially cooling off the fire that builds the house.

For a Hyrox athlete doing concurrent training (running + strength + HIIT), this is a double problem:
1. **Strength side:** CWI blunts mTOR signaling for muscle protein synthesis. You're undermining the sled push strength, farmers carry grip endurance, and wall ball power you're trying to build.
2. **Endurance side:** There's emerging evidence that chronic CWI may also dampen mitochondrial biogenesis and capillarization — the same Zone 2 adaptations you need for your running engine.

**When ice baths ARE appropriate:**
- After your race or a full race simulation (competition recovery, not training adaptation)
- When you have two high-intensity sessions within 24 hours and need to reduce soreness to perform
- During a deload week when you're not seeking adaptation, just recovery

**What to do instead for daily recovery:**

| Recovery Tool | Evidence | When |
|---|---|---|
| **Sleep 8-9 hours** | Strong — #1 recovery intervention | Every night |
| **Foam rolling** | Moderate — reduces DOMS, improves blood flow | Post-training, 60-120 sec per muscle group |
| **Active recovery walk/easy spin** | Moderate — enhances blood flow, psychological benefit | Day after hard sessions, 20-40 min at <60% HRmax |
| **Post-workout nutrition** | Strong — 1.0-1.2 g/kg carbs + 0.3 g/kg protein within 2 hours | After every session |
| **Compression garments** | Weak-to-moderate — small DOMS reduction | Overnight after hard sessions |

Drop the daily ice baths. Save them for after your simulations and race day. Your body will thank you with better adaptations across every training domain — strength, endurance, and muscular endurance. The discomfort after training is the adaptation happening. Let it happen.
What about sauna? I've heard that helps with endurance.

Sauna is a different story — and actually useful for Hyrox athletes, but with important caveats.

**What sauna does for endurance:**
- **Plasma volume expansion:** 2-3 weeks of regular sauna use (15-20 min at 80-100°C, 3-4x/week) increases blood plasma volume. More plasma = more blood per heartbeat = lower HR at any given pace. This is essentially a legal form of altitude training. Laukkanen et al. (2015) showed cardiovascular benefits from regular Finnish sauna use.
- **Heat shock protein activation:** Sauna triggers HSP70 and HSP90, which protect proteins from damage during exercise stress. This may improve exercise tolerance.
- **Heat acclimation:** If your Hyrox race is in a warm venue (indoor venues can get hot with hundreds of athletes), regular sauna exposure helps your thermoregulation system adapt.

**The same blunting concern exists:**
Just like ice baths, sauna immediately post-strength training MAY interfere with hypertrophy signaling. The evidence is less robust than for CWI, but the theoretical concern is valid — any extreme temperature manipulation post-exercise can disrupt the inflammatory signaling cascade.

**My recommendation for your Hyrox prep:**

1. **Use sauna 2-3x per week, but NOT immediately after strength training.** Wait at least 3-4 hours, or do sauna on separate days from your strength sessions.
2. **Timing:** After easy runs or on rest days is ideal. Post-run sauna won't blunt your aerobic adaptations because those adaptations are driven by different signaling pathways (AMPK, PGC-1alpha) that aren't heat-sensitive in the same way.
3. **Protocol:** 15-20 minutes at 80-100°C for traditional Finnish sauna. 2-3 rounds with 2-3 min cool-down between rounds.
4. **Rehydrate aggressively:** 500ml+ fluid with electrolytes immediately after. You'll lose significant water and sodium through sweat. Weigh yourself before and after — replace 1.25-1.5x the weight lost.
5. **Don't add sauna if it compromises sleep.** Late-evening sauna raises core temperature, which needs to drop for sleep onset. Keep sauna sessions at least 2-3 hours before bed.

Bottom line: sauna = strategic tool for plasma volume and cardiovascular health. Ice baths = reserve for competition and acute recovery only. Both require timing awareness to avoid blunting your training adaptations.

If you've done serious CrossFit, your rowing mechanics are probably solid. The key difference: Hyrox rowing comes after BBJ, so it's about managing the fatigue transition. Use the row as tactical recovery — don't sprint it like a CrossFit workout. Target 24-28 SPM with strong leg drive. Damper at 5-6 for your weight class.

**Burpee Broad Jumps — Partial Overlap**
You know burpees, but Hyrox BBJ is different from CrossFit burpees. Key differences:
- The BROAD JUMP component is the differentiator. Jump forward (60-70% max distance), not up.
- It's 80 meters of continuous work, not a set number of reps in a WOD. Pacing discipline matters more than speed.
- Step-up method is recommended even for fit athletes — save your heart rate for 80m of sustained work.

**Stations Where You Need to Adjust:**

**SkiErg — Moderate Concern**
CrossFit uses the SkiErg but often in short bursts. In Hyrox it's 1000m and it's Station 1 — you can't redline it. Target 30-34 SPM with lat-dominant pulls. Resist the CrossFit instinct to go all-out.

**Sled Push — Technique Warning**
CrossFit athletes tend to push sleds with bent arms and an upright posture because gym sleds are often lighter. Hyrox sleds at 152kg (Men's Open) on competition carpet feel MUCH heavier. You need a **45-degree body angle** and short rapid steps (120+ SPM). Film yourself — you're probably more upright than you think.

**Sled Pull — Major Adjustment Needed**
CrossFit rarely programs hand-over-hand sled pulls in a confined space with rope management. This is unfamiliar territory. Key technique: brace your feet FIRST, then pull hand-over-hand with hip extension. Keep the sled moving — static friction is your enemy.

**Farmer Carry — Different Context**
In CrossFit, farmer carries are usually short and heavy. Hyrox is 200m at moderate weight (2x24kg men's) after 6 runs and 5 stations. It's a postural endurance test, not a grip test. Shoulders retracted, chest up, move as fast as possible — time under tension is non-linear.

**Sandbag Lunges — The CrossFit Trap**
CrossFit athletes often lunge with short, quick steps (quad-dominant). In Hyrox, this DESTROYS your quads before wall balls. Use 0.9-1.1m steps with posterior chain emphasis. This will feel weird coming from CrossFit — train it before race day.

**The Running — Your Likely Weakness**
Let's be honest: most CrossFit athletes undertrain running. Hyrox has 8km of running that accounts for 55-60% of your total time. If you're not running 20-30+ miles per week, your running will cap your overall performance regardless of how strong your stations are. Start building run volume immediately.

**Under 75 minutes:** Your pre-race fueling should carry you through. Carry 1 gel as insurance — take it if you feel energy dipping around Station 4-5.

- **Gel #2:** After Station 5 (rowing), during Run 6 transition
- **Gel #3 (optional):** After Station 7 (lunges), if you have 20+ minutes left

**Practical tips:**

1. **Carry gels in your shorts pocket or a thin running belt.** Have them accessible without stopping.

2. **Take them during Roxzone transitions or early in a run** — not during stations. You need your hands free and your breathing controlled.

3. **Wash down with water** from the Roxzone water stations — sip 100-200 ml with each gel.

I can do CrossFit Hero WODs and long chippers. Does that mental toughness transfer to Hyrox?

Yes — and this is one of the most underappreciated advantages CrossFit athletes bring to Hyrox. But the mental game is different in specific ways you need to prepare for.

**What Transfers Directly**

Long chippers and Hero WODs build three mental skills that Hyrox demands:

1. **Tolerance for sustained discomfort.** A 45-minute Hero WOD teaches your brain that feeling terrible doesn't mean you should stop. Hyrox is 60-90 minutes of continuous work. Your brain has already learned to manage that duration.

2. **Task management under fatigue.** In a chipper like Filthy Fifty, you're managing effort across 10 different movements. In Hyrox, it's 16 tasks (8 runs + 8 stations). The cognitive skill of "what's next, what's my plan, what's my pace" under severe fatigue is identical.

3. **The ability to keep moving.** CrossFit athletes have practiced hundreds of hours of "don't stop, keep going, one more rep." This eliminates the quit impulse that non-CrossFit athletes face at Station 6 when their legs are burning.

**What's Different About Hyrox Mental Demands**

1. **Pacing discipline over intensity.** In CrossFit, mental toughness usually means "go harder." In Hyrox, mental toughness means **"hold back now so you can maintain pace later."** The athlete who sled pushes at 95% effort and then walks the next 1km run loses to the athlete who pushes at 80% and maintains a consistent run pace. This requires a different kind of mental control — restraint, not aggression.

2. **Monotony management.** Hyrox has 8 x 1km runs. The runs feel the same. The scenery is an indoor convention center. There's no variance, no surprise workout — just the same race format every time. CrossFit athletes are trained for variety. Hyrox demands mental engagement during monotonous repetition.

3. **Negative split management.** Your 8th 1km run needs to be nearly as fast as your 1st. In CrossFit, it's acceptable (even expected) to slow down in later rounds. In Hyrox, the best athletes run negative or even splits. This requires confidence that you have more in the tank — a mental skill built through practice, not just toughness.

**How to Train the Hyrox Mental Game**

1. **Practice race simulations monthly.** Run 4-8 stations with 1km runs between. Pre-set your target splits for each run. The goal is NOT to go as fast as possible — it's to hit your target splits consistently. This trains pacing discipline.

2. **Do 100-rep wall ball sets.** Monotony tolerance. You'll want to stop at 60. Don't. Break it into sets of 10, use your breathing routine, and practice the mental self-talk that keeps you going.

3. **Practice the "next run" moment.** The hardest mental moment in Hyrox is finishing a grueling station (sled push, lunges) and forcing yourself to start running again. Train this specifically: finish a heavy station, stand up, and immediately start jogging — even if it's a shuffle. The first 200m is the mental battle. After that, your body finds a rhythm.

Your CrossFit mental toughness is real and valuable. Now refine it: from "go harder" to "go smarter, go longer, go more consistently."

I can only get about 7 hours of sleep during the week because of my work schedule. What can I do to minimize the damage?

Seven hours is below optimal but above the danger threshold. Let me give you a damage mitigation strategy that works within your constraints.

**First, understand what 7 hours costs you:**
- You're missing approximately 1-2 hours of optimal recovery per night
- REM sleep (motor skill consolidation) is disproportionately lost because it dominates the final sleep cycles
- Growth hormone release during deep sleep is likely adequate (deep sleep occurs in the first half of the night)
- Injury risk increases at <7 hours (1.7x per Milewski et al.), but 7 hours is right at that threshold

**Damage Mitigation Protocol:**

**Strategy 1: Sleep Banking on Weekends**
- Sleep 9-10 hours on Friday and Saturday nights
- Arnal et al. (2015, 2016) showed 1-2 weeks of extended sleep before a high-load block can buffer against subsequent restriction
- This isn't a perfect solution, but it partially offsets weekday debt

**Strategy 2: Strategic Napping**
- 20-30 min nap before 2:00 PM
- Set an alarm — naps >30 min risk entering deep sleep and causing grogginess
- Even a 20-min nap improves alertness, reaction time, and mood
- If you can nap before your PM training session, you'll train better

**Strategy 3: Maximize Sleep Quality Within 7 Hours**
- **Consistent wake time** (±30 min, even weekends) — this is more important than bedtime
- **Cool room: 18-20°C**
- **Blackout curtains** — any light exposure during sleep reduces deep sleep quality
- **No caffeine after 12 PM** — with only 7 hours, you can't afford to lose 41 minutes to late caffeine
- **No alcohol** — it fragments sleep architecture even when total duration looks normal

**Why you feel terrible right now:**

The taper paradox is real and well-documented in sports science. When you reduce training volume by 20-30%, several things happen simultaneously:

1. **Glycogen supercompensation begins.** Your muscles are storing more glycogen than usual because you're consuming the same (or more) carbs but burning less. Glycogen binds water at a 1:3 ratio, making your legs feel heavy and swollen. This is FUEL being stored for race day. It's a good thing.

2. **Reduced endorphin production.** High-volume training produces endorphins that mask fatigue and improve mood. When volume drops, you lose that chemical buffer. Easy runs feel harder because the perceived exertion isn't being dampened by training-induced endorphins. Your ACTUAL fitness is fine.

3. **Psychological withdrawal.** You've been training 10+ hours per week for 13 weeks. Your brain is addicted to the training stimulus. Reducing it creates anxiety, restlessness, and the irrational belief that you're getting weaker. This is mental, not physical.

4. **Inflammatory clearance.** Your body is finally clearing the chronic low-grade inflammation from 13 weeks of heavy training. This healing process can temporarily make you feel achy, sluggish, or "off." It's your body repairing micro-damage that accumulated during training.

**The science of what's actually happening to your fitness:**

- Mujika & Padilla (2003) showed that a 2-3 week taper preserves (or slightly improves) VO2max while allowing muscular recovery.
- Performance typically improves 2-6% during a well-executed taper.
- Fitness markers (VO2max, lactate threshold, running economy) are NOT lost in 2-3 weeks of reduced volume. It takes 4-6 weeks of complete detraining before measurable fitness loss occurs.
- What IS lost in 2-3 weeks without maintenance: some blood plasma volume (recoverable within 48 hours of racing) and some neuromuscular sharpness (maintained by strides and short sharp efforts).

|---|---|---|---|---|

| Week 16 (race week) | 8.5 mpw | 0 | 0 | Mon: 3mi easy + strides. Wed: 2mi + 2x30sec pickups. Fri: RACE. |

- Foam roll and stretch: 15-20 min daily. This is maintenance, not development.

What should my sleep quality look like? I track with a smartwatch but I don't know what the numbers mean.

Good that you're tracking — now let me teach you which metrics actually matter and what to target.

**The 5 Sleep Quality Metrics That Matter:**

| Metric | Your Target | Why It Matters |
|--------|------------|----------------|
| **Deep sleep (SWS)** | ≥1.5 hours (15-20% of total) | Growth hormone release is synchronized with slow-wave sleep. Critical for tissue repair, glycogen repletion, and anabolic processes |
| **REM sleep** | ≥1.5 hours (20-25% of total) | Motor skill consolidation, learning, emotional regulation. Your SkiErg technique and wall ball rhythm consolidate here |
| **Sleep efficiency** | ≥85% | Time asleep divided by time in bed. Athletes average only 80.6% vs 88.7% in non-athletes (Leeder et al., 2012) |
| **HRV during sleep** | Stable or trending upward | Nocturnal HRV reflects parasympathetic recovery. A sustained drop >1 SD below baseline for 3+ nights signals incomplete recovery |
| **Wake after sleep onset** | <30 minutes | Excessive WASO fragments deep sleep and REM cycles |

**How to Interpret Your Watch Data:**

**Deep sleep below 1 hour?**
- Likely causes: alcohol, late caffeine, screen time before bed, elevated stress
- Fix: No alcohol within 3 hours of bed, no caffeine after 1 PM, 60 min screen-free before sleep
- Deep sleep occurs predominantly in the first half of the night — going to bed earlier (not sleeping later) is the most effective lever

**REM sleep below 1 hour?**
- REM dominates the second half of the night
- If you're cutting sleep short (alarm at 6 AM), you're truncating your richest REM window
- Fix: Earlier bedtime to protect morning REM cycles

**Sleep efficiency below 80%?**
- You're spending too long in bed awake
- Paradoxically, the fix may be going to bed LATER and getting up at the same time — consolidating your sleep into a shorter, more efficient window
- Then gradually extend bedtime earlier as efficiency improves

**HRV dropping for 3+ consecutive nights?**
- This is an early warning sign of overreaching
- Reduce training intensity, add a recovery day, prioritize sleep to 9+ hours
- Do not return to high-intensity training until HRV normalizes

**Practical hierarchy:** Deep sleep > total sleep time > sleep efficiency > REM > HRV trend. Focus on getting enough total sleep first — the architecture improves when duration is adequate.
